user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtMessage:
```c
void UtMessage(uint8 MessageType, const char *File, uint32 Line, const char *Spec, ...)
{
    UT_Snprintf_Buffer_t Buf;
    va_list              va;

    va_start(va, Spec);
    vsnprintf(Buf.Text, sizeof(Buf.Text), Spec, va);
    va_end(va);

    UT_BSP_DoText(MessageType, Buf.Text);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
UT_Snprintf_Buffer_t Buf;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown fragment: Buf is declared as an object of type UT_Snprintf_Buffer_t, not as a pointer, so Rule 8.13 (about pointer types being const-qualified when possible) is not violated here. (A possible violation scenario would be if UT_Snprintf_Buffer_t were a typedef for a pointer type — e.g. typedef char *UT_Snprintf_Buffer_t; — in which case Buf would be a pointer to a non-const-qualified type and could violate Rule 8.13 unless the pointed-to type is made const-qualified when appropriate.)
